div.head: THE PREFACE vnto the vvhole discourse.
div.p: WHEN I first set footing into this present businesse, my purpose vvas not (no not in my most secret thoughts) to enter into any point of controuersie, or to giue occasion of offence, or dislike vnto any: only my resolution vvas, plainely, and positiuely (as the course of my studies had euer bent, and caried me) to glaunce at a mayne point of doctrine (it comming but obiter in my vvay) directly vvarranted, nay lineally deduced frō the vniforme consent of all ancient times; bequeathed vnto vs by the perpetuall tradition, and practise of the Church.

But yet since, contrary to my probable persuasion, certaine priuate spirits (vvhose faith is their ovvne fancy) ytching rather after prophane nouelty, and hereticall innouation,
thē abiding the vvholsome doctrine of sacred Antiquity, and the Churches dogmaticall tradition, haue, by all meanes, laboured to impugne my doctrine, and to defame my person: I haue thought my selfe in conscience, and duty (both before God, and man) obliged, asvvell for the generall satisfaction of all, vvhom this present businesse may any vvay concerne, as for my ovvne dischardge in particular (being the party herein especially interessed) briefly to compile, and publish the vvhole cariadge, and progresse of this matter, in the ensuing treatise; humbly recōmending, and euer submitting my opinion vnto the graue, and infallible iudgmēt of the Church, at vvhose feete, and tribunall alone prostrating my selfe, J must stand, or fall: as also referring my self, vvith the moderate deportment of my cause, vnto the syncere iudgement of the discreete, and impartiall Reader.
